—I also direct my question to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the minister to the 1996 World Competitiveness Yearbook , which ranked Australia only 43rd, in terms of our current account balance, out of the other 45 countries surveyed. Can the minister explain the causes of this woeful performance? How will the government tackle this problem and how will this boost our competitiveness, growth and employment prospects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chapman for that question. People who have read the press today will be aware that the 1996 World Competitiveness Yearbook has ranked Australia—and this is on the basis of a ranking by thousands of business persons around the world; it is done by the International Institute for Management Development, a Swiss based survey firm—on the overall ranking as 21st out of the 46 countries surveyed.

ANSWER.PARA: All of our major trading partners and competitors rank above us. Many of the individual rankings are appallingly worse than even the ranking of 21st out of 46. Over the last 12 months of the former Labor government, we have slipped from 16th to 21st on that competitive rating.

Senator Chapman referred to our rating in relation to our current account performance—that is, our performance in terms of our external accounts. He is correct that the survey puts us at 43rd, almost right at the bottom of the league table, in relation to our external accounts performance.

The simple fact again is that, although we have all known for a long time that the current account deficit problem facing Australia has been a major problem for Australia, the former government in its 13 years in office was never prepared to tackle that problem. The result of course was lost jobs, lost investment, lost economic growth and, as noted by the competitiveness report, lost competitiveness.

In simple terms the current account deficit is the amount by which national savings are insufficient to fund national investment and the difference is the amount we have to borrow from overseas to pay for our expenditure. The competitiveness yearbook indicates that our savings shortfall, as I have said, is the third worst of the other 45 countries surveyed.

Economic commentators and governments around the world have increasingly recognised that high current account deficits can constrain economic growth. High current account deficits can lead to higher interest rates and make the economy more vulnerable to external shocks with the resulting loss and damage in the area of our national sovereignty that that brings.

That is particularly the case when governments contribute to the current account deficit by running irresponsible fiscal policies. The then Treasurer, Mr Keating, as I am sure we all remember, warned of the dangers of excessively high current account deficits 10 years ago in 1986, when he said that you cannot fund—and at that time it was a $12 billion a year deficit—that deficit in perpetuity every year and then the interest on that debt and on the debt before it.

What we have seen under this government is a continual erosion of the dangers that the then Treasurer warned us of 10 years ago—a warning that the former government took no action at all to meet. Our policy, with regard to the current account deficit, is going to be based on action. It is not going to be based on the rhetoric that we have heard for the last 13 years. We will reduce the underlying budget deficit by $4 billion in 1996-97 and in 1997-98. We will not allow the Commonwealth to continue year after year to drag down national savings and compound the competitiveness problem that is so apparent in this report. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. The government's purchasing policy for paper encourages buyers to `purchase goods and services with the least harmful environmental effects'. With the removal of the sales tax incentive on recycled paper for ordinary consumers, what impact does the government expect on the economic returns for post‐use paper collection for public and private sector collectors? What impact does the government expect on the export of used paper and the import of finished paper products? Will the government undertake a definite preferential buying program to support the purchase of post‐use recycled paper products wherever possible? Under the principles of competition policy and with current departmental budget cuts, how will environmental costs be incorporated into purchasing policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there were four questions there, but they really boil down to two. The first question was really asking what are the implications of the tax concessions on recycled paper—what concessions there are—and the second question was in relation to the government's purchasing policy. I think Senator Margetts's questions can be narrowed down to those two issues.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as the first question is concerned, since 1989, sales tax provisions relating to recycled paper products have changed considerably. Prior to 1989, recycled paper products did not attract any preferential sales tax treatment and were taxed at the general rate of 20 per cent. In 1989, an exemption was introduced for a range of recycled paper products. The scope of the exemption was reduced in 1992, as Senator Margetts will recall.

The then government agreed to provide transitional assistance to specialist manufacturers which had been disadvantaged by the decision from 1992-93 to 1993-94, after which the assistance ceased. The remaining exemption for certain 100 per cent recycled paper products was removed from 1 November 1995. Those products include writing, drawing or printing paper, envelopes, notepads, accounting journals and ledgers. The exemption was removed, as I understand it, Senator Margetts, because it proved an inefficient method of achieving the previous government's environmental objectives.

BREAK.PARA: The removal of the exemption is consistent with the recommendation of the Industry Commission in its 1991 report on recycling. The report found in particular that the exemption was difficult to administer, that it provided no assistance to less than 100 per cent recycled paper products, that it provided incentive to divert waste paper from more traditional and efficient uses to the production of paper eligible for the exemption, and also that it impeded efficient industry development.

In regard to the second question, in terms of the present government's purchasing policy, our purchasing policy for recycled paper products encourages buyers to purchase goods and services with the least harmful environmental effects consistent with value for money principles. Government buyers generally purchase their paper requirements through a common use arrangement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I answered this question four years ago.

—You can answer it again if you like. This arrangement consists of a panel of approved suppliers who supply a range of paper products, including recycled products. The buyers guides issued to government buyers include as much information as is available from product evaluations and supplier information so that informed purchasing decisions can be made.

BREAK.PARA: There is no data on which to base any conclusions about the impact that the removal of the sales tax exemption might have on the economic returns of paper collectors or the export of used paper and the import of finished paper products. The government will continue its policy of encouraging buyers to purchase goods and services with the least harmful effects consistent with value for money principles. Value for money does remain the essential test against which any procurement outcomes must be justified. Value for money decisions, however, require consideration of all costs, benefits and alternatives, and environmental costs are an important part of the equation.

That is why, if you were prepared to look at the facts instead of being blinded by ideology, you would see that the Bureau of Industry Economics in 1995 said:

The overall picture from the price comparisons is one of Australia having to run to keep pace with international counterparts and barely managing to keep up. A World Bank study in 1994 on the welfare consequences of selling public enterprises said that the benefits to the British consumers of the sale of BT amounted to 4.150 million pounds.—

in other words, close to $A10 billion—that is to consumers—Prior to divestiture the revenue boost came primarily from raising prices, whereas after divestiture it came from increasing real output. Since March `84, the year of BT's privatisation, the average BT business customer bill has been more than halved in real terms. At the same time the average residential bill has fallen by about 30 per cent.
They are the facts. Why don't you stick to them? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), to a question without notice asked by Senator Schacht today, relating to the proposed partial privatisation of Telstra.

In the statement of 8 May he clearly appoints CS First Boston to carry out the scoping studies.

What I really want to find out is whether you have given further instructions to CS First Boston to do scoping studies on what the value of Telstra would be if it was privatised by non‐legislative means.

We believe that Telstra would be substantially reduced in value if you privatised it by non‐legislative means. In particular, you cannot avoid the issue that if you do not put legislation through exempting the privatisation process from state stamp duty, between $1 billion and $2 billion—estimates vary—could be charged by state governments in stamp duty on creating a new corporate structure. That would clearly come off the $8 billion. If not, you might try to get this very large sum of money back in negotiations with the states by threatening to cut their states grants. That would then create an argument with the state governments. If you accept paying the stamp duty, you will be down at least $1 billion on the $8 billion. We are not arguing that it is necessary for that to be done to make it simple but if you go the non‐legislative route you are not able to exempt, therefore the full power of the Corporations Act and all those things that go with it are part of the process. There is also the complicated issue concerning any disallowable instruments that affect Telstra but are in the Telecommunications Act. Where do they stand? Will they have an impact? If you go the non‐legislative route you cannot change those disallowable instruments. There is also the whole question of the existing liabilities that Telstra has—debt liabilities, borrowings—and how they would be dealt with in a non‐legislative way. For example, there is comment around that you cannot transfer the staff in the Telstra corporation to another corporate entity without their having some rights. If the stamp duty alone is more than a billion dollars and is paid to the states, that reduces the amount to $7 billion, or even less.

PARA.BREAK: If you do go the non‐legislative route—no matter how much you get, it will be substan tially less than $8 billion—does the government still make an absolute commitment to put $1 billion into the environment program, or will that be substantially reduced, proportionately, because you are getting proportionately less than $8 billion? These are fundamental issues and are why we want to know what instructions you have given CS First Boston for their scoping study.(Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), to a question without notice asked by Senator Margetts today, relating to recycled paper products.
I am afraid that Senator Short's answer probably was not on recycled paper. In Western Australia an inquiry into recycling stated in its executive summary:
Western Australia is committed to the goal of halving the solid waste going to landfill (on a per capita basis) by the year 2000.

We are unlikely to achieve that goal unless, as a community, we buy and use more recycled goods. We are, it seems, very good at collecting, sorting and stock piling recyclable materials, but fall down when it comes to creating markets for those materials by buying recycled products.
Under the `Key Finding' heading, the primary finding was:
The cost of recycled paper can be significantly reduced for Government by bulk buying through common use contracts.

Other findings were also quite important. I will read them out in good time. I just want to emphasise this. Basically it means that if each individual department makes its decisions one by one, it is never going to make that a more competitive buying option. That will not happen unless they have a proper policy that departments in general buy those goods and make a market that is worthwhile.

I want to emphasise that a major effort for local and state governments over the last 10 years has been to convince people, households and businesses to recycle. The reason for this is economic. It costs a dramatically increasing amount of money to throw things away. Tips fill rapidly and new tip sites are difficult to find within urban areas. Transport of waste out of cities to non‐urban sites is expensive. Small towns do not really want to become the rubbish tips of cities. Waste collection is expensive. Building new tips in an environmentally sound manner is often very expensive, especially if they are on top of a water mound. The situation has become critical enough globally that a few years ago the United States considered taking 10 per cent of its domestic waste and sinking it in a lagoon in the Marshall Islands.

Then there are the ecological impacts of both waste disposal and of wasting material resources and the energy used to make them. In particular, paper is used and thrown away on a massive scale. We are chopping down our forests and chipping them. We are not doing it for building materials; we are doing it so we can make paper and throw it away. We are converting old‐growth forests into rubbish and filling our tips with it, and it is costing us a fortune. We chip timber and we send the chip and pulp overseas. We import paper. We spend millions to collect paper from consumers because the alternative is to spend millions to throw it in the ground.

The single biggest barrier to paper collection is the low price collectors get for paper. In many cases they cannot sell it in Australia. They have to sell it to Asia in competition with the United States and Canada, who also send wastepaper to these markets. This is absurd. We have resources, both forests and wastepaper, and we sell them cheap. We import paper—that is absurd. We spend millions to encourage people to recycle.

The largest and most inexcusable component of urban waste is paper. The former government initially made recycled paper exempt from sales tax as an incentive to industry. It said it would remove the exemption when the Commonwealth shifted to virtually exclusive use of recycled paper, creating an Australian market. It has now removed the incentive to consumers and seems to be buying less and less recycled paper itself. It is abandoning the support of a recycled paper industry just as it is starting. The industry has started slowly, but it is here.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to differentiate between a couple of definitions of `recycled'. `Recycled' cannot mean simply cleaning up the scraps from paper making, the offcuts from pads and so on. The recycling we want and need is recycling the paper we encourage consumers to sort and recycle, the paper we collect. This is the paper we need a market for. This is the paper we need to recycle.

Because of the hypocrisy of paper makers who do not use real waste, environmentalists have now had to start talking about post-use recycling to make it clear that they are talking about recycling real wastepaper. I think it is a disgrace that the Australian government does not actively pursue a purchasing policy with the express aim of ensuring that the paper it consumes—and we consume a lot—should be virtually exclusively post-use recycled paper.
There have been questions about whether recycled paper can be used in all applications. The Western Australian report dispels many of the myths about these problems. The `Executive summary' says:
. Recycled paper is compatible with most office equipment, including photocopiers.
. Electronic equipment capable of using recycled paper should be preferred in future purchases.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to a question without notice asked by Senator Colston today, relating to the contribution of property sales to the defence budget.

I must say it is a very rare event that I comment on defence matters post-portfolio responsibility, but it was a classic example of a minister in this place spending four minutes in answering a question and one minute in answering a supplementary question while not addressing one word to the question that Senator Colston asked. You can make two assumptions here: either Senator Newman did not know what she was talking about or there is a scam going on about the defence budget that she did not want to reveal here today.

Senator Newman talked about the extensive cuts to the defence budget over recent years. The fact is that this federal defence budget has been reduced by 2.25 per cent in real terms over the last five or six years. That is a disappointment to me but, if you compare that with New Zealand that has come down 22½ per cent in real terms, the United States that has come down 20 per cent in real terms, the United Kingdom that has come down 16 per cent in real terms and Canada that has come down beyond 15 per cent in real terms, one can see that it is quite a modest reduction.

But Senator Colston's question to Senator Newman asked, in essence: will you keep your promise to sustain the defence budget in real terms and will you avoid the scam of reducing the budget but then forcing Defence to get into a round of property sales to make up the difference? For the last six years Defence has had the absolute right to sell property and retain 100 per cent of that revenue in its own budget in lieu of any increases to the defence budget because of constrained economic circumstances.

Hints have been dropped. Mr McLachlan dropped the hint on PM, I think, that there would be more property sales. Senator Newman comes into this chamber on the question of RAAF base Laverton—and I do not disagree with what they are doing there—saying there will be property sales later this year. Those sorts of property sales are likely to increase over the next three years for one good reason: when the property market was down during my tenure in the defence portfolio, we resisted the temptation of bargain basement sales. We waited until the property market improved so that Defence could garner maximum revenue advantage from property sales. So for six years we have had a policy that any property sale that Defence undertakes—this is not equipment; we are talking about property now—all the revenue comes back to Defence and is reinvested.

The simple question today was: would the minister, on behalf of the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan), guarantee that they were not going to cut the defence budget and bodgie the figures through property sales? That was the essence of the question. We did not get one word of an answer on that particular matter. We still require Senator Newman to come back into this chamber later this week and answer that aspect of the question—and so she should.

We know there have been secret meetings on this and secret plans made but, as I pick up the hint of that, much of those secret plans hinge on Defence having to cough up 20,000 hectares of land and hand it over to private enterprise for absolutely nothing.

Think of the replacement cost that is going to go to the defence budget to replace the whole Holsworthy base. We have just put a storage revolution through the defence force centred on Holsworthy. Think of the effect on the property values of Wattle Grove, a model urban development, and think about replacing all that infrastructure; who is going to pay for that? If Holsworthy were to ever become the site, Defence would be entitled to a commercial return. I must stress that every time Defence buys property it does so with full tote odds; no‐one gives it a concession these days.

Instead of filibustering for four minutes, making sexist comments about husbands packing their wives off, Senator Newman should come back into this chamber and give an additional answer on Wednesday or Thursday and answer this particular matter. If the government does get up to a scam on this—and only if they do—I am going to pursue them time and time again until they actually reveal what they are up to.

ANSWER.PARA: I found Senator Newman's statements to be quite offensive and I think a lot of people—a lot of women—also found her remarks offensive. I know it is reasonable for you to poke fun at women, that women are a weapon you can utilise; but I do not think that view is shared by the community at large. It is quite reasonable to assume that there are families in which women still run a budget. People in a family can divide up the chores in any way they think fit. What concerns me about Senator Newman's comment is not that it endorses the fact that some women carry out a budget but what it says about the relationship between a man and woman in a marriage. Clearly Senator Newman's comments rely upon an inequality in a relationship which allows the husband to determine the value of a woman—if she does not measure up to the values that her husband specifies, then he has the right and the option to discard her as he chooses.

Senator Newman's remarks rely on a power relationship within a marriage that allows a man to discard a woman as he chooses. That may be an acceptable proposition for some members of the coalition but it certainly is not an acceptable proposition as far as I am concerned. It is certainly not an acceptable proposition as far as the men and women of Australia are concerned. Most people see a marriage relationship as a relationship of equality, where one party does not have the right to discard the other at a whim.

While I am raising these matters, I wish to briefly mention some of the comments made by Senator Herron. I can see that this issue excites those opposite, because they have been very noisy this afternoon. Senator Herron clearly said that he does not know who was around him because he is used to being surrounded by beautiful women. Why would you remember that one woman was there and not another? I have the view that that is not the case and that women have a value in what they say and in what their ideas are. If a woman is present, she is entitled to be remembered because of the value of her contribution and not just because of what she looks like.

If you are in a situation where you do not have an answer, make a bit of noise, have a bit of a laugh, confuse the issue, but do not use the women of Australia as the brunt of that joke, because they do not deserve it. They are entitled to be treated as people of value in this community.

The bill will amend the taxation laws relating to provisional tax, share buy‐backs and gifts. The share buy‐back and gift measures were introduced into the parliament late last year but were not debated.
The bill will give effect to the coalition's election commitment to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor for the 1996‐97 income year to 6 per cent.

Under Labor the uplift factor was set at 8 per cent for the previous three income years. This rate exceeded growth in income subject to provisional tax in these years—more than double the rate of actual income growth in one of these years. It was merely a tax grab and a way to bring forward revenue collections. It placed a heavy cashflow burden on small business and self‐funded retirees.

The amendment is an important example of the coalition delivering on its election promises. The government is committed to the small business sector and self‐funded retirees, both of whom will benefit from this measure.

The bill will give effect to the 1995‐96 Budget announcement that the full buy‐back price of a share in an off‐market share buy‐back is to be treated as consideration for ordinary income and capital gain purposes. Relief from double taxation is provided by reducing the amount of the ordinary income gain or capital gain by the amount of the dividend included in assessable income or paid out of profits. If the dividend is rebatable, it will not create or increase a capital loss or allowable deduction.
A market value rule is also to apply to off‐market share buy‐backs. Any excess over the market value of a share that is a dividend will not be frankable.

These amendments will apply to share buy‐backs that take place after 7.30 p.m. AEST on 9 May 1995, unless they occur under certain transitional arrangements. The amendments have the potential to prevent a future loss to the revenue.

The bill will amend the gift provisions of the income tax law to allow deductions for gifts of $2 or more to The Polly Farmer Foundation, the Australian Games Uniform Company Limited and the Cobram and District War Memorial Incorporated Fund. The bill also extends the time for tax deductibility of donations to the Shrine of Remembrance Restoration and Development Trust and The Sandakan Memorials Trust Fund.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: That the following questions relating to the qualification of one or more senators be referred to the Court of Disputed Returns pursuant to section 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918:
(a) whether there is or will be a vacancy in the representation of South Australia in the Senate for the place for which Senator‐elect Jeannie Ferris was returned;
(b) if so, whether such vacancy may be filled by the further counting or recounting of ballot papers cast for candidates for election for senators for South Australia at that election;
(c) alternatively, whether in the circumstances there is a casual vacancy for one senator for the State of South Australia within the meaning of section 15 of the Constitution;
(d) whether any other senator aided, abetted, counselled or procured, or by act or omission was in any way directly or indirectly knowingly concerned in, the matters giving rise to paragraph (a);
(e) if so, whether there is a vacancy in the representation of the relevant State in the Senate for the place for which that senator was returned; and
(f) if so, whether in the circumstances there is a casual vacancy for one senator for the relevant State within the meaning of section 15 of the Constitution.

In speaking to this motion I make the point right at the outset that this is not just another motion of the Senate. This motion raises an issue which goes very much to the core of the constitution of this place and is one which needs to be addressed. It is important because, unless we address it, as we have said consistently over the last few weeks, the status of decisions taken by this place could very easily be called into question.

This is not a question of numbers in the Senate, because we have made it clear that we would ordinarily provide a pair in these sorts of circumstances. This is putting the Senate on notice about the possible incapacity of one of our future members to hold a position here, the consequences of a doubt over that particular person and the impact that that doubt would have on the process of this place.

The first point that needs to be addressed is that the responsibility is primarily on the government. Over the years when issues like this have been raised ministers responsible for electoral matters have taken the initiative and have referred matters like this to the Court of Disputed Returns of the High Court. It is quite apparent that in this particular instance the government is shirking its responsibility. Not only are they not prepared to send this matter off, but they have taken a consistent attitude all the way through of obstructiveness and deceptiveness on this issue, trying to conceal facts and not face the music.

Given that, and the fact that it has taken us so long to get documents from the government about this matter—and we believe there are still more to come—we believe that there is no other option but for the Senate to confront this issue. It is up to us; it is part of our responsibility and is very clearly within our ambit of power.

What is at question here is whether there has been a breach of section 44 of the constitution. Section 44 of the constitution is that particular provision which ensures that a person who holds an office of profit under the crown shall be incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator or member of the House of Representatives. That is the issue that we raise.

In respect of that issue, there are three component parts that need to be addressed. The first is whether a senator-elect is a person who comes under the ambit of section 44 of the constitution—that is, whether the period when a person is a senator-elect is covered in the constitution. It is our contention that Senator-designate Ferris has a number of problems in respect of that issue.

BREAK.PARA: The government would have us believe that there is advice from a QC saying, `Everything is all right. She's Jack, mate.' But it was the government's own Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Jull, who on 3 April this year wrote to Senator Minchin and basically said, `Hold your horses. Although I appreciate that the matter is one on which a different view can be taken, my own opinion is that section 44 is applicable to senators‐elect. I have concluded that not only is this the safe view to adopt, but that it is also the correct one.

I was fortified, obviously, on seeing the advice of the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, on this point. Mr Jull wrote to Senator Minchin on 3 April. He referred him to Durack's advice and then said:
I should add that the issue was raised again in 1984—

SPEECH.PARA: For our purposes, there are two stages under the electoral act: one is when you are a senator‐elect and the other is when you take your place. You become a senator on 1 July, even though you have not been formally sworn in, which is when you sit. It is before and after 1 July that is critical in this exercise. They had the opportunity, under section 353, to petition the Court of Disputed Returns. They chose not to do that. They were not prepared to put their money on the table. They simply wanted to wait until the parliament resumed, so they could put the Senate's money on the table and force Senator‐elect Ferris to go off and defend herself in the High Court, which is not a cheap thing to do unless you throw yourself on the mercy of the court and go there unrepresented. BREAK.PARA: More importantly, the whole structure of the act is that, if you are only a senator‐elect, you petition. If it is in respect of either a senator, under 376, or a question concerning a vacancy, then the Senate may resolve it. It does not have to; it always retains a discretion. I would have thought what is does above all else is to look at the evidence and decide whether indeed there is a prima‐facie case. You do not simply say, `There may be an issue here,' or `Perhaps there is a doubt,' or `Wouldn't it be interesting to have this resolved?' That is why I presume you use the expression `we tend to agree.' In other words, you are inclined to think that there may be something to this.

I suggest to you that it is a very unsafe basis on which to then solemnly resolve to refer a matter to the High Court. What the act requires, in these circumstances where you are out of time and have not petitioned within 40 days, is that you then must wait until the senator takes, in this case, her place in the chamber. Then section 376 applies.

What is likely to happen here, and I suggest will happen, is that when this matter goes to the High Court, they will ask themselves, `Are we now dealing with any question respecting the qualifications of a senator?' The answer has to be no, because by no stretch of the imagination was Jeannie Ferris a senator at the time these matters arose. As we know, by definition, there can only be 76 senators in the Senate chamber. Therefore, she could not possibly be a senator at that time, because she would be the 77th. Indeed, you could throw in all the other senators‐elect as well. She clearly was not a senator, so the High Court would say, `Well, the other leg of section 376 is: `respecting a vacancy.' It does not say `a potential vacancy'; it says `a vacancy.'

One can envisage a situation where, for example, a senator‐elect dies.That happened in 1938, with a gentleman by the name of Barnes. That matter was then referred back to the relevant state government and they replaced Barnes because a vacancy had occurred. It was not done under this section. There was not any resolution of the Senate requesting the state government to do it. That is the only situation in which you could say a vacancy occurs. Here, you have the prospect of a vacancy if the court finds in your way. What you are really saying is: we want you to presume an offence and therefore a vacancy. Then, having done that, we want to argue the case about whether there is a vacancy. It just cannot be right in logic.

The proper course to take is to wait until 1 July. Then you may well take the view that a question respecting the qualifications of a senator does arise because, as I think is common ground, if you are found to have taken an office of profit under the crown then that renders your term void. So it is void ab initio; it goes back to the very start. That was what Senator Wood found. Even though he had been in the chamber for 18 months or two years, once he was ineligible he was ineligible from the beginning. The same would apply here.

So, to the extent that Senator-elect Ferris had contravened, say, section 44 of the constitution, which is what I think is at issue, rather than any sections of the acts, that would render her ineligible to retain her seat and she would be held not to have been a senator at any time. But the time to make that reference is at the time she is a senator; otherwise there is no section of this act that allows the Senate to refer the matter to the High Court, because there is not a vacancy and it is not a question respecting the qualifications of a senator—it is simply respecting a potential vacancy, and that potential turns on the reference of the question. So it is certainly tautological, but it is quite inadequate in terms of the proper processes.

You always have to proceed on the basis that if parliament does not specifically provide for an offence or quasi-offence then it is presumed to have intended not to do it.
