It would be very interesting if it is a section 15. This may all become a pointless exercise, because I am sure the South Australian branch would then reappoint Senator Ferris to the post. I am fairly certain that would be the normal political behaviour of any of us. There is some doubt as to that in as much as in the case where someone dies between the close of nominations and, I think, taking their place here, the electoral act and other things indicate that there would need to be a count through.

Those are questions the High Court would need to answer. I found it very interesting tonight that Senator Alston did not get to factors other than the legal factor. He tried to mount no defence of government action in this particular matter.

The matter was first raised on the first sitting day. We were accused of filibustering on this issue. It was not us who took 19 days to answer a very simple question: had the Attorney-General's Department given the Department of Administrative Services advice on this matter? The answer, obviously, from all the documents in the return to order, is that they could have come back the next day and said, `Yes, but we're not going to provide any of the legal advice.' I think it is quite appropriate not to put down every piece of legal advice to government. But they could have answered it on 2 May. Instead, we had no answer for nine days, which prompted someone on our side to ask Senator Short a question and Senator Short took it on notice.

When you read the return to order, there is all of this advice, all of these documents generated, these meetings—all of this occurred, yet Senator Short could not answer these very simple questions. Surely, he had a brief, going through all of that. Was it just stage fright? Did he just panic? Why didn't he answer those questions? And why did Senator Vanstone, on 20 May or thereabouts, answer on behalf of Senator Short those particular questions?

That prompted our side of politics to move for a return to order. It is from that return to order and many other things on the record that one can start to understand the chronology of events. I will just run through them rather quickly.

On 18 March, Senator Minchin writes, to whom it may concern, confirming his wish to appoint Senator Ferris to the position of assistant adviser from 18 March until 28 June inclusive. He confirms the salary details of an ASO6, with a salary of $40,080 per year and a ministerial staff allowance of $11,200—very interesting pay for a volunteer. He then signs a work contract on the same day. Ms Ferris signs a work contract; Ms Dunstan witnesses that contract.

On 18 March, Senator Minchin writes to Ms Feely of the Prime Minister's office, advising of wanting to appoint Ms Ferris. On 20 March, Ms Ferris starts travelling on the travel warrants according to her job. And where does she go? Adelaide‐Canberra, Qantas 474, first class, costing $499. She returns, Canberra‐Adelaide, on 21 March on Ansett 185. On 25 March, Senator Minchin writes to Minister Jull advising he has—and I quote:
. . . appointed Ms Jeannie Ferris to the position of Assistant Adviser to me in my capacity as Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister.
He goes on to note the appointment period of 18 March to 28 June. He also notes in the letter that Ms Ferris is a senator‐elect due to take up her position on 1 July.

We then go to 28 March. The DAS pay sheet for Ms Ferris, for pay period 19, indicates that Ms Ferris is paid three days salary and three days MSA, which is a gross of $604. After tax, there is a net of $512.64. We then go to pay period 20, where Ms Ferris is paid 10 days salary and 10 days MSA, with a gross of $2,015.16; tax comes out and she nets $1,391.86.

On 28 March, the Department of Administrative Services faxes a cover sheet referring to the Ferris request to recommence contributions to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. Here we have a volunteer joining the Commonwealth superannuation scheme! No one knows more about this than Senator Sherry and our very gracious Acting Deputy President. They would be very surprised to know that volunteers can go into the superannuation scheme.

We then have a whole series of travel around the country, for which travel warrants were obviously signed off by Senator Minchin or one of his delegated staff members, in which Ms Ferris attends to the duties of her office. We then have the rather curious correspondence on 1 April 1996. I am conscious of the date but apparently it is actual correspondence. Ms Ferris having been in the job for 13 or 14 days, Senator Minchin writes to Ann Richards of the Department of Administrative Services, referring to his prior correspondence between himself and DAS and noting that he could appoint an adviser on a commencement salary of $49,932. He advises that he wishes Ms Ferris to go on that. Pretty good work, after 13 days, to get a 22 per cent pay rise! It is good money if you can get it. Again, a volunteer getting a 22 per cent pay rise is pretty good. We then have a whole series of travel commitments.

However, someone in the Department of Administrative Services does some good staff work. Right throughout this, I have very little criticism of Mr Jull and the Department of Administrative Services because I think they have done their job pretty well. They twigged to this—that this was a problem, that this may well disqualify Ms Ferris. So Graham Semmens' file note indicates he will advise Mr Jull in a submission regarding these matters. That submission goes in on 2 April. Ms Ferris is still flying around the country doing her duty.

Mr Jull, the Minister for Administrative Services, signs a letter, above the submission, to Senator Minchin, advising that he does not intend to approve Ms Ferris's appointment at this stage. He attaches a copy, very significantly, of Senator Durack's opinion on the meaning of section 44 as it applies to senators‐elect.

At that stage Ms Richards, whom I have mentioned before, urgently faxes the National Australia Bank, confirming a phone call that day to retrieve the second tranche of salary, and gets that returned. Ms Ferris does not know about that yet. The matters go on until 11 April, when there is a meeting here in Parliament House. I put on the record that I misrepresented this the other day and Senator Minchin berated me for it. I have to say the documents in the return to order are handwritten and very hard to read. Nevertheless, I acknowledge it was not on Easter Monday, but on 11 April. For that, I apologise. Nevertheless, a government which put out those documents should have gone back to the original person and got a typed version rather than a handwritten one. However, I regret that.

They met here in Parliament House—that is, Ms Ferris, Graham Semmens and Senator Minchin. They discussed the fact that the payment of three days salary to Ms Ferris may have jeopardised her position as a senator‐elect. They advised that DAS had discussed the matter with the Attorney‐General's Department and stated that DAS had not paid the next salary payment due to Ms Ferris, and explained why. In fact, they had paid it but they then retrieved it from the bank.

The file note noted that this was okay with Ms Ferris and pointed out that the constitutional position was not one for DAS but rather for them. And then Ms Ferris travels home, which I think is the last time she uses departmental resources to travel or salary or travel allowance.

It is only on 19 April—eight days later—that Ms Ferris writes to DAS returning the money and advising that she will not take up the appointment. It is only 19 April that Senator Minchin writes to DAS cancelling the appointment. So, effectively, from 18 March to 19 April, Ms Ferris was holding an office and an office of profit under the crown, if it is so defined under the MOPS act, and in fact received remuneration, travel allowance, airfares—and cab fares, as we found out today in those circumstances.

That is basically the chronology of it and therefore there is a very strong case that Ms Ferris was employed. I do not think that that can be contradicted very much. And I think there is a very strong case that because she was employed by a member of the Executive Council she held an office of profit under the crown.

The one thing I am not going to comment on is whether the High Court would therefore say that she has forfeited her position as a senator‐elect. That is for them to determine; I cannot. It has been the general view, expressed not only in the Durack thing but time and time again, that senators‐elect cannot take government employment. For those elected in 1980 there was an eight‐month wait for those who were, in some senses, public servants. A lot of hard times; a lot of people stood out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus was one of them.

—Senator Bolkus was one of them but there were many who had to stand out—school teachers, a whole range of people. Senator Baume had to stand aside, as I understand it. There was a whole range of people that actually made that commitment and did not take the risk. Maybe it is a pity that someone did not and we could have, at least, had guidelines for the future. I am not saying that this case should be taken to the High Court just for an advisory opinion for future people. If that is a side benefit, that is good, but it should not go just for that reason. So that is the chronology.

BREAK.PARA: In the course of this debate, a few other remarkable things have come up. First of all, I listened to Senator Hill's defence of Ms Ferris, who described this as a witch‐hunt. It is no such thing. Senator Hill's contribution today reminded me of the old maxim by Lenin; he gave her the same support as the rope supports the hanging man. I really thought it was a weak defence. I was rather pleased in some way that the old journeyman middleweight, Senator Alston, the star of Melbourne's lesser magistrates courts, only really went to the legal matters and did not go to any of the matters of cover‐up—and there have been plenty of those in this particular matter.

The one area that has not been fully explained to me regarding cover‐up or veracity goes back to Senator Minchin's statement to this chamber on 22 May. I am really puzzled by this. Senator Minchin said:
Following the federal election, Ms Ferris, on my advice, sought information regarding the status of a senator‐elect in relation to section 44 of the constitution.

While it is my strong view that section 44 does not apply to senators‐elect, I felt it prudent that Ms Ferris obtain her own legal advice before considering any public sector employment in the period after the election and before 1 July.

Well, where is that advice? When did it occur? Or was this just a post facta defence of Senator Minchin that he, as a political professional, was smart enough to think of? Or is the advice that he is talking about the advice that was tabled here today? That is a critical question as to Senator Minchin's future—absolutely critical that he did not mislead the Senate on these matters.

This legal advice, which has been tabled by Senator Hill today and which naturally none of us has had a chance yet to read and comprehend, is dated 17 May. If there is not another set of legal advice, if this is the legal advice on which they based their activity, then Senator Minchin's statement here in the parliament on 22 May could be described at the very least as grossly dissembling. He was invited to clarify this matter by me in two speeches that day and never once addressed it. It does go massively to his credibility in these particular issues.

A few other matters have been brought up here today. One of them was Senator Hill asking how we could, in some ways abusing taxpayers' money, refer this matter to the High Court. So I went back as he was speaking to check where he was on the day that we had the debate on the Wood case. I found that he was in divisions that day, so he must have been around Parliament House. No division was called on the Wood matter; it was referred off without a division. Implicit in that is Senator Hill's full support for that process back in 1989. And he comes in here today and says that we are in some ways abusing Senate power or wasting taxpayers' money when there we had Senator Hill himself implicitly voting to send these matters off to the High Court.

Senator Hill said that had read the advice of the Clerk of the Senate and he did not agree with it. Why not? That is only one set of advice; we now have a second set of advice before us from Ms Wheeler QC and we have the Durack advice. The point I want to make is that it is beyond my ability to reconcile that conflicting advice, and I want to suggest that that is why we pay High Court judges. That is why the Electoral Act and other matters are written in the manner they are: to let judges ultimately determine these matters.

In summary, these matters could have been addressed much more quickly by government. There is no excuse for a 19‐day delay in Senator Vanstone's answer. There is no excuse that, in answering for Senator Short, all the detail was omitted from Senator Short's answer. We asked whether she had had any pay or condition. No answer. When the additional answer was put down in this place on 20 May, or whenever it was, there was no attempt to answer that section of the question.

Then we had Senator Minchin coming in here to give his personal explanation, which must be one of the most cleverly crafted pieces of work I have ever seen. I have already mentioned that he referred to legal advice—presumably the Wheeler advice which was not commissioned until 17 May—as though it had been produced before 18 March. If I am wrong in saying that, where is the advice? I do not want to read the advice because it may be private to Ms Ferris and Senator Minchin, but I want to know that it existed and that we were not being duped in this place just to maintain the political professional reputation of an apparatchik from South Australia. People know that I do not use that term in a condemnatory way.

I want to know whether that has all been constructed in this statement. Because, frankly, if it has been, given the Prime Minister's glorified code of conduct, Senator Minchin should be dismissed as parliamentary secretary on that ground alone. Whether he should be dismissed for political stupidity, as Senator Schacht has unkindly said, is another matter. I find it hard to understand how a so-called consummate political operator could make these basic mistakes and jeopardise Ms Ferris's immediate career in this chamber. I cannot understand how he could do it. Senator Hill is wrong when he says that we are trying to run some vendetta against Ms Ferris. There is no evidence whatsoever to point to our doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The moderates in the Liberal Party are running the campaign.

—As Senator Schacht interjects, the real dirty work on Ms Ferris, the real knifing, is coming from her own side and not from this side. I do not wish to not see her take her place in the Senate; she won the vote. But, if she is disqualified by Senator Minchin's abject stupidity, I think a question can be raised as to his future. So there are two questions. As to the one of stupidity, we have all been guilty of that over the years. The second question is whether he has grossly misled the Senate in his dissembling statement issued in here on 22 May. As to that, we need more of an explanation.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Alston made the point that, in his own legal analysis, he thought this motion was being moved at the wrong time. He would much prefer it to be moved when there are 37 coalition senators here and the numbers change a little. When challenged by me by way of interjection whether he would vote for the reference in August, we got the normal barrister's reply: `I can't confirm or deny that.' All he is doing by those arguments is putting it off.

As I have said here once before, in one sense and one sense alone it is very much in Ms Ferris's self‐interest to have these matters determined as close to the swearing‐in date as possible. Even when she is sworn in and takes her place in here, I understand that the matter can still be taken to the High Court. The penalty which could apply and which I think was updated in the Webster case would be $200 a day. That will be a much more expensive proposition than doing it in this particular way.

In summary, I believe the first three parts of this motion should go to the High Court for determination. It is not for this chamber to determine this matter. There are too many political biases and there is not the expertise here to deal with it. It should go to the High Court for determination, and hopefully we will have a determination well before 1 July. Those efforts by the government to cover up this matter have been exposed by the return to order, and Senator Minchin's dissembling statement in this chamber has now been exposed. He should come in here today to explain the sequence of events and his actions, but he has been absent. Rather than directly reflect on—

TALK.START.PARA: —He has already; you just don't want to believe it.

—I wanted to qualify that by saying I also understand there are occasions when senators have other duties. I should at least qualify my challenge for him to come in here. There may be circumstances that prevent him from doing so, and I acknowledge that for the record. When he comes into this chamber I would like him to explain what his comments were regarding her seeking legal advice. Where is that advice? If it merely becomes the advice given by Ms Christine Wheeler—which is hard to pronounce at times, given other events in England in 1963—
—You are showing your age.

—I have made this mistake before, so I want it noted for the record that I have got it right for once. If that is the legal advice and that is the only legal advice, then we have Senator Minchin cold: grossly misleading this place. That will become a much bigger issue than Ms Ferris's eligibility to take her place in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is dealing with quite a serious matter relating to the constitution and one which obviously should be treated as such. That is why I was most concerned with parts (d), (e) and (f) of this motion which get to the politicisation of this particular matter. I am very pleased that those parts are going to be excised from the motion. Senator Bolkus was drawing a very long bow indeed to place (d), (e) and (f) in the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion is that the various questions relating to the `qualification of one or more senators be referred to the Court of Disputed Returns pursuant to section 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act'. That motion will have to be amended to `one senator', which has also been acknowledged by the statements of Senator Bolkus and Senator Ray. I do not know whom else they could be talking about. Perhaps Senator Bolkus wants to refer all of our positions or qualifications to the Court of Disputed Returns. I presume what is meant by that particular—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at (a).
—I am looking at (a), but I am looking at the introduction, `To move that the following questions relating to the qualification of one or more senators'.
—This is the same wording as we used in Wood.
—It may well be, but you need to look at that. I will not delay the Senate very long. I was here during the Robert Wood case and also the Webster episode.

SPEECH.PARA: There are four, actually, but there are three ways that are open to question the qualifications of a senator. Before I do that, I remind the Senate of section 44, which I will go to in a minute. But the three ways are: section 355 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act which provides for a petition. That has been canvassed quite considerably here and 355 says:

BREAK.PARA: Subject to section 357, every petition disputing an election or return—
an election or return—
in this Part called the petition shall:

And it sets out what it shall do. The petition must be lodged within 40 days after the notification of that choice or appointment. Referring to section 44 of the constitution and referring to the question of holding an office of profit under the crown, it says:
Any person who—
Holds any office of profit under the Crown—
et cetera—
shall be incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator or a member of the House of Representatives.
Clearly, section 355 of the act relates to the question of the choice of the senator. It does not relate to the question of whether the senator is eligible to sit. The constitution has an `or' there:
shall be incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator or a member of the House of Representatives.

One would have thought that if one were incapable of being chosen to be a senator, one would have been incapable of sitting as a senator. No doubt that is a matter that would otherwise be discussed. But, so far as section 355 is concerned, the opportunity for petitioning the court has ceased; it is no longer there.

I think Senator Bolkus was suggesting that the date on which the Governor‐General received the writs was 21 April. If you were taking it from that particular standpoint, a couple of days are still left. But, in fact, it was the state governor of South Australia who issued the writ and the provision in the constitution relating to the return of that writ, of course, relates to its return to the state government, namely, return to the sender. The actual timing of when the state governor received the return of the writ was 11 April. So that, in fact, the time has run out for section 355 to operate.

The second availability is the provisions in section 376. I am not going into the question of the facts. The facts have been tabled in this Senate and there has been and will be considerable argument about the implications of those particular facts. Section 376 provides that:

Any question respecting the qualifications of a Senator or of a Member of the House of Representatives or respecting a vacancy in either House of the Parliament may be referred by resolution to the Court of Disputed Returns—

That is what is proposed here. There are a number of questions but two come to mind: whether the alleged breach of the constitution that Ms Ferris did hold an office of profit under the crown whilst seeking to be chosen as a senator, is a matter that the Court of Disputed Returns could deal with. Does the constitution, by the wording of section 44, mean a person who may at that time have held an office of profit under the crown—that is, during the time of the election and before the return of the writs—so that her incapability of being chosen would be a matter for consideration of the court pursuant to this particular resolution?

That is a question the answer to which I am not sure of, given the fact that section 355 was quite specific about the time limits and that those time limits, of course, have gone. The courts may not be able to consider that matter. There is a question as to whether Senator-elect Ferris, Ms Ferris, was holding an office of profit under the crown after she was chosen—that is to say, after the writs were returned to the Governor of South Australia. I am not sure of those facts, and I do not know whether anybody around here is either. But I think the opposition should be conscious of that particular matter. The opposition may be referring this to the Court of Disputed Returns and find, if the other question is unable to be considered—that is to say, the eligibility of that particular person to be chosen during the course of the election—that that is excluded and we are back to square one.
The second part of the argument, of course, is in the constitution where it states:
. . . shall be incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator or a member of the House of Representatives.

Clearly, Ms Ferris currently is not the holder of an office of profit under the crown. Also, she is not—or is she?—currently a sitting member. So is she incapable of sitting as a member? The issue really is whether a senator is a sitting senator before that senator has sat. I think that is an issue to be taken into account when considering this particular motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a matter the High Court would rule on, I presume, Senator.
—Yes, but it is also a matter for us to consider when we are considering a motion such as this.
—They are the umpire.
—Yes, they are the umpire, but we should not absolve ourselves of our responsibility.

—Senator Murphy reminds me that there is also the issue of being chosen to sit at a time when that person is incapable of sitting. Ms Ferris has been chosen to sit, and the question is whether she was capable of being chosen to sit. That is a question, of course, under the provisions of 355 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, and we are out of time on that particular question.
—No, we are only out of time with that method of challenging it.

—Yes, with that method of challenging it we are definitely out of time. There are no two ways about it, but I have raised the point as to whether that little word `or' in the constitution is significant. It seems to me to be somewhat significant. Nevertheless, I suppose that is something that will be argued at length.

BREAK.PARA: The third issue is the provision of section 46 of the constitution. That section enables any individual to sue for the recovery of $200 per day for every day that a senator has sat when that senator is incapable of sitting, under the constitution. Of course, I suppose that is a matter for consideration of the parliament, of us here.

One thing worries me about what we are doing at the present moment. There was a bit of cross‐talk between Senator Abetz and Senator Ray. As Senator Ray was not talking at the time, it will not be in Hansard, but that bit of cross‐talk engendered the thought in my mind that one should raise the question as to whether the costs of Ms Ferris in defending herself should properly be borne by the parliament, if we are to send the matter to court.

I must say that I am concerned that a number of matters have been raised politically in this chamber about Ms Ferris. I do not know Ms Ferris from a bar of soap, nor do many other people. But certain matters were raised in this chamber, and I thought that they were improperly raised in this chamber or that they were raised in an improper manner, and certain inferences were made when Ms Ferris was not here to defend herself. That is another question. However, parts (d) (e) and (f) are out of this particular motion.

I must raise the question with the opposition as to whether they intend to include in this motion a provision that the costs of her defending herself would be borne by the Commonwealth, either by this parliament or by the executive government. I tried to find out what was the case in Robert Woods's case and I am not able to ascertain whether he in fact had his costs covered. I do not know, but I do raise that matter quite seriously.
I would like to hear more from the opposition as to why they would want to have this matter adjourned until 1 July—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the government.

—Did I say the opposition? I am sorry: why the government wants this matter deferred or adjourned to 1 July. I would have thought that perhaps the most sensible way would be to have the issues referred off to the Court of Disputed Returns and also, either in this particular motion or in a subsequent motion, to move for the costs of Ms Ferris to be borne.
—Can I just say that I have already referred that to Senator Bolkus as our spokesperson. He will sum up in reply on this motion.
—I would be grateful. The issue has got to be cleared up.
—I have already asked him to consider that request. He will respond on behalf of the opposition in his right of reply on the motion.

—Thank you. Clearly, one way or the other the issue of eligibility must be cleared up, and I would have thought it would be better for the government to do it this way rather than to wait until 1 July, and then in August, when Ms Ferris is sworn in, she takes the risk, if she sits in this parliament, that somebody could at a later time take the matter to the High Court and sue Ms Ferris for $200 per day for every day that she sits. I would have thought that under those circumstances it is a bit much of a gamble. The other way of doing it, of course, to get rid of the whole thing would be for a resignation to take place and then a reappointment be made to the casual vacancy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate to support the motion moved by Senator Bolkus. He has already indicated, as we have, that we are aware of the amendment from the Greens and the Democrats to excise paragraphs (d), (e) and (f). I think Senator Bolkus recognised that the numbers are probably there for that to occur, but that is not the substantive issue that we have before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to make a couple of comments on the contributions made by some of the previous speakers in this debate. I turn to Senator Alston's remarks that you cannot take action until Senator Ferris is sworn in as a sitting senator. I wanted to refer to section 360 of the electoral act, which deals with the powers of the court, that is, the High Court operating as the Court of Disputed Returns. Section 360, clause (3), says:

Without limiting the powers conferred by this section, it is hereby declared that the power of the Court to declare that any person who was returned as elected was not duly elected, or to declare an election absolutely void, may be exercised on the ground that illegal practices were committed in connexion with the election.

What clause (3) implies to me is that this takes effect once the person was declared elected, before they even took up their seat in the Senate. I was at the ceremony where Senator Ferris was declared elected because I was also declared elected at the same time in early April. The writ was returned to the state governor on 10 April, declaring Senator Ferris elected with the other six senators from South Australia.

I believe that is a reasonably clear indication that the Court of Disputed Returns, which is the High Court in this case, can deal with somebody who has been declared elected. It does not have to wait until they are actually sworn in, which happens some time after the return of the writ. I think the High Court does have the power. I have to concede that there are older hands around this place on legal matters with due experience who might say that that is not the right interpretation, but it does seem to me an indication that on the date you are declared elected this takes effect. I say again that I was a witness to her election being declared because I was at the ceremony when it happened, where I was also declared elected. So I think that point from Senator Alston can be dismissed.

The issue that Senator Harradine raises with some concern is that the 40 days has run out as far as a petition to the Court of Disputed Returns is concerned. As I understand the act, that is to do with the actual conduct of the election, not with the eligibility of a person to stand. This is an area where I think the major point of dispute is, and I believe the High Court is the only relevant body to rule on that eligibility question.

I point out to Senator Harradine that the opposition has been a bit hung out to dry on this issue of the 40 days anyway. In order to seek information, we raised the issue on the first day the parliament returned—that was on 30 April, if I remember correctly. It was not until 22 May, when Senator Minchin made a substantial statement, that a whole range of issues then became clearer to the opposition, the Senate and the people of Australia. Clearly, Senator-elect Ferris had been receiving some payment, in some form or other, from the Commonwealth government of Australia. Senator Minchin said that she had received three days pay and some expenses for travel to other parts. Subsequently, when we got the return to order, we found it was much more substantial than anything Senator Minchin had suggested in his statement on 22 May.

I say to Senator Harradine: 22 May just so happens to be 40 days after the writ was returned by the state government. It seems to us that there was a government plan for Senator Minchin not to make his statement until the 40 days was up so that this technical point—that the petition could not be lodged—could be raised. We do not accept that point, because it is a question of eligibility, not a question of the conduct of the election.

The opposition thinks it is more than coincidence that Senator Minchin gave his major statement on the issue on 22 May—three weeks after we first raised the issue in the parliament. I say to Senator Harradine: you cannot, in commonsense, allow a process to take place whereby, when relevant questions are asked about what is going on, when a matter has been legitimately raised and when we as a Senate are waiting for the information to come back, someone can delay the process hoping that the 40 days falls out. I would have thought any court, under process, under administrative law, would have said that the question was first raised, information was sought, on 30 April. Of course, it was after Senator Minchin's statement that the Senate decided to put a return to order on papers and documents. The whole case spilled out when those documents were tabled earlier this week. Even today we had further material tabled by Senator Hill.

We think Senator Minchin has a case to answer about why he waited to make his statement until he could see the 40‐day period was up. That is a very important point to us. Did the government take a deliberate decision to wait till the 40 days was up and then argue the case? Senator Harradine has raised that. I think we have said why we think the timing of the government's statements is unacceptable.

Senator Minchin relies greatly on the statement of advice from Ms Wheeler. He said that Senator-elect Ferris was advised to go and get this opinion, or get some legal opinion, before she took up employment with Senator Minchin. The implication so far has been that that advice was from Ms Wheeler QC. However, the date on the document of advice that has now been tabled is 17 May, which is about a month after Senator-elect Ferris started employment on the staff of Senator Minchin, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister. I think the first letter in which Senator Minchin says he appointed Ms Ferris is dated 18 March.

There may be other legal advice that has not yet been tabled, but we are now of the view that there is a substantial case that the advice he said he got was actually the advice of Ms Wheeler on 17 May. If that is really the case, then Senator Minchin has, by at least omission—the best light you could put on it—misled the Senate. At the worst, he has deliberately misled the Senate by saying that this advice from Wheeler is the advice that Senator-elect Ferris took on board to enable her to take up the position with him on 18 March. If it is not, I think it is imperative that before this parliament finishes this week—preferably tomorrow or even before this debate finishes—Senator Minchin should tell us whether Wheeler's advice is the only advice that Senator-elect Ferris took. Then he has to explain how the advice tabled in parliament today is dated 17 May—a full month after Senator-elect Ferris took up her position.

The next question we would ask is: who paid for Ms Wheeler's advice? Was it paid for by Senator-elect Ferris? Was it paid for by the Liberal Party of South Australia? Was it paid for by the Australian government? These are relevant questions which, I suspect, in the end, if this motion does lead to the matter going to the High Court, will become matters that the High Court will become interested in. The Senate deserves a decent answer to those questions. Who paid for the advice? Who commissioned the advice? The dates are really imperative. If there is any other advice that Ms Ferris took on before 18 March, she should fire up Senator Minchin or the government to table that advice as well. Otherwise, it seems to us that there has been a clear case of rewriting history, rewriting the facts, to suit the government's case. The government has been sprung since 30 April when the parliament first sat. That case is now to us looking overwhelming.

There has been retrospectivity in this case. I am interested in the Liberal Party's position on retrospectivity in any area because the issue of retrospectivity has always been—and you, Mr Deputy President Watson, have been one of the great commentators in this place, opposing retrospectivity in law and in legislation—one of the great policy principles of the Liberal Party. I do not have the same view about retrospectivity from time to time, but I do accept that it is a matter you do not take on lightly. Here we may have a case where Senator Minchin has retrospectively tried to fix the advice to cover his trail in making a very stupid error in appointing—as all the evidence now tabled in the parliament shows—Senator-elect Ferris on 18 March.

Senator Minchin says the appointment took place on 18 March; that is, before the writ was declared, before she formally became senator‐elect. One notes from the appointment document, though, that he appointed her only to 28 June, two days before the term of the new Senate starts. Everybody in South Australia knew on election night on 2 March—it was the clearest cut election in the Senate in South Australia since proportional representation was introduced—that the Liberal Party had three quotas, the Labor Party had two quotas and the Democrats had one quota. Everybody knew who were the six senators who were going to be elected in South Australia.

There was no distribution of preferences at any stage in the South Australian count to get a senator elected. The only distribution was the transfer that took place on the tickets of each of the three parties. There was a very small transfer from Senator Stott Despoja. She got 14 per cent, with a little left over. The Labor Party, unfortunately, got only two quotas with a little left over—a couple of per cent—and the Liberal Party got three clear quotas.

Everybody knew, including Senator Minchin as a former State Director of the Liberal Party, that Senator Ferris was going to be elected to the Senate when the count was formally concluded. He cannot escape from that. It is why, in his letter of appointment on 18 March, even before the Senate count was formally completed, he appointed her only until 28 June. He knew that on 1 July she would become a senator in this place and that she would be paid from 1 July, even though she would have to wait until 20 August to be sworn in.

Let there not be any mystery position, `I didn't really know whether she was going to be elected.' I have never seen such a clear‐cut result in my 30 years in Labor Party politics as in this South Australian Senate election. The result—who the six senators were—was clearly established on election night. Senator Minchin knew that and that is reflected in his 18 March letter of appointment. He knew where she was going: into the Senate.

The next thing we come to is the advice that has been flying around as to whether the senator‐elect is eligible to stand in the Senate and the impact her holding an office of profit under the crown would have. So far, we have different pieces of advice. We have the advice from Miss Wheeler on behalf of Senator‐elect Ferris and Senator Minchin, saying that there is no doubt that the senator‐elect is able and eligible to take her place. We have the advice of former Senator Durack, a former Attorney‐General. That has been tabled in this place. It is referred to in Mr Jull's letter warning Senator Minchin. He refers to the advice of Senator Durack—a Liberal Attorney‐General, a long‐serving and distinguished senator in this place. He said that office of profit under the crown means senator‐elect and that there is grave doubt about the process.

We find it interesting that a former Liberal Attorney‐General's advice is disputed by the Liberal Party in this place. Advice from the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, was made available yesterday. He makes it clear that he believes there is an overwhelming case that the office of profit under the crown starts from the period of the election, not the period of being sworn in.

TALK.START.PARA: —He never said overwhelming.

—You may well be right, Senator Abetz. That is not our point. Our point is that the advice of people who have considerable experience in this area, one a Liberal Attorney‐General and one the Clerk of the Senate, is that the matter is in dispute, it is in doubt.
—He said it is likely; you can't misquote him.

—I am not misquoting him; I have just read through the four pages of the Clerk's opinion and I think it is pretty clear cut that on any balance of commonsense probabilities people would say this raises considerable doubt about the eligibility of Senator‐elect Ferris to take up a place in the Senate. I do not know whether Mr Evans is correct but I have to say—
—You have always been a strong supporter!

—I will take that point on, Senator Kemp. It is very true that I have had disputes with the Clerk on a number of issues about the management and running of the Senate. I have disputed some of the articles he has written about becoming a republic. He and I have a difference of opinion on that. One thing I have seen since 1987 when I came to the Senate is that the Liberal Party in opposition treated the advice and the word of the Clerk of the Senate, who most of that time has been Mr Evans, as absolute law—like the Ten Commandments.
—And the Labor Party.

—Not just the Liberal Party. The minor parties have also taken the advice of Mr Evans, the Clerk, about the running and procedures of this place overwhelmingly as writ. You have his document before you. He is the person who consistently advised you how to operate as an opposition in this place through the years I have been here when we were in government. You now want to dispute him and say, `The advice is doubtful,' and so on.
—He says that himself; he says it is likely.

—Of course. That leads me to the point that there is doubt. There are differences of opinion; but there is no doubt that there is a major issue that there is argument about, under the constitution: the eligibility of Senator‐elect Ferris, who was holding an office of profit under the crown. There is only one way to resolve that, to go to the one body that is above us on all of these matters: the Court of Disputed Returns, which is the same as the High Court. Let them decide. We may be wrong, Senator Kemp and Senator Abetz. You may be absolutely right. They may rule that she did not hold an office of profit under the crown and may be eligible to sit here.
—You hounded her.
—We have not hounded her at all. We have raised issues to sort out what—
—You hounded her! Face up to it!

—Let me just say one thing, Senator Kemp, about this hounding. You ought to have a good look at a number of Liberal Party members in South Australia who have leaked consistently to the media. In an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of Saturday week ago John Ferguson, the parliamentary roundsman for the Advertiser , wrote an article headed `White ants are taking a piece of the action'. This is all about the Ferris case. In the article he makes quite clear that this article was sourced from people within the Liberal Party. He mentioned in this article:

BREAK.PARA: Despite parliament yet to be told whether or not Ms Ferris's position is in any real danger, some Liberals already have started moving to install a member of the State Executive and a leading moderate, Ms Maria Kourtesis, to replace Ms Ferris.

He has said that came from the Liberal Party. The advice and some of the hints we have been getting and the view that this should be chased have come from Liberal Party members in South Australia. They have been salivating at this because Ms Ferris's preselection from the so-called conservative faction was a hotly disputed ballot in South Australia with Ms Kourtesis. Ms Ferris won it and Ms Kourtesis came fourth on the ticket.

There is no doubt, as that article and our own experience show, that this is a matter of great controversy in the Liberal Party and there is a substantial section in the Liberal Party which wants Ms Ferris knocked off, to use that political term. That article says it all in great detail. A further part of the article states:

The Ferris issue flared on Monday might at the Liberal Party State Executive when former party president Ms Vickie Chapman openly disputed who should pay for any legal costs flowing from the issue. One line being pushed to undermine Ms Ferris is that the State branch faces a bill of $200,000 in legal costs because the matter "inevitably" will go to the High Court.

There was a report only a few days ago in the Australian on this issue where the journalist commented, without naming the minister, that a senior cabinet minister from South Australia and a recent cabinet minister bagged Ms Ferris. It did not name the person, so you can say it is unsourced and has no substantiation. So Senator Kemp, to say that we have hounded Ms Ferris is absolutely outrageous.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, my point of order is that it is unparliamentary in my view for innuendos to be directed at Ms Ferris when she is not here to defend herself.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, the established cases of protection refer only to members of this parliament—that is, to senators and members of the other House. However, it would certainly be a courtesy for anyone speaking in either this chamber or the other to choose themselves not to trespass upon civilities that are given to anyone who is a senator here.

INTERJECT.PARA: A senator-elect strictly does not have the same privileges as a senator, but it would be my ruling that it would be very much to the advantage of debate in this chamber if any senator gave to a senator-elect the same civilities we expect for each other. Senator Schacht, in so far as you have made any reflection, I ask you to simply withdraw that reflection.

TALK.START.PARA: —If people think there was a reflection, I withdraw it. I was responding to an interjection, which was particularly nasty to the opposition, that we were hounding Ms Ferris. I wanted to point out that there was plenty of published material around pointing out that the internal machinations of the Liberal Party in South Australia are really the ones that may be doing more to hound Ms Ferris than anybody else from any other political party.
—I was going to the question of whether Senator‐elect Ferris is a person capable of sitting and, if so, do the standing orders apply to her?
—It is a good question. Maybe the High Court could rule on that as well, Senator Harradine.
—I ask that senators direct their remarks through the chair.

—Of course. We believe that the evidence that has been tabled in this parliament clearly demonstrates a strong case that there was an office of profit under the Crown held by Ms Ferris for a period of time after the federal election on 2 March. We believe the only way that can be resolved is to do it in the correct way, which is to refer the issue now to the High Court and let it determine it.

BREAK.PARA: Taking on Senator Harradine's very good point, this ought to be resolved one way or the other before she turns up on 1 July. It would be outrageous pressure on her to sit in this place while we are debating it. She could then be sued for $200 a day.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be when she is sworn in in August.
—True. Okay in August, but then as every day goes by there are votes in the Senate. I believe it is natural justice that we should resolve this matter. It may be resolved in her favour.

BREAK.PARA: The final thing I want to comment on, which other senators have mentioned, is this section of the constitution. Clearly, I do not think the founding fathers believed that this clause would create such difficulties in interpretation in a practical sense for common, ordinary people being elected in view of the fact that many millions of people in one form or another may be claimed to at one stage or another have an office of profit under the Crown. It is something that we are stuck with. The only way to change it is through a referendum, and maybe one day there can be agreement on that. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that is before the Senate is one of a serious nature. I join with Senator Harradine, who, I think, was trying to lift the level of debate to the actual questions in issue rather than descending into the political mud‐slinging that unfortunately occurred from members on the other side. Clearly, what we are talking about is the future of a woman who put her herself up for election, submitted herself to the people and was overwhelmingly elected. Now there is an argument being put forward, which I will go through in detail, suggesting that she is not entitled to take her seat in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a serious matter and I do not think it reflects well on this chamber, or on those who have partaken in the debate to date and have tried to limit the scope of the debate to some fairly cheap political points. Indeed, the motion was founded on the principle of trying to take some cheap political points. I am pleased to see that the Labor Party are now no longer to going to pursue, in effect, half of their motion.

Senator Bolkus claims credit for this motion, and that is fine. But as Senator Harradine has pointed out, if there is going to be the deletion of subparagraphs (d), (e) and (f), then clearly the motion will need further amendment in relation to the words `one or more senators'. Also of interest to me is the contribution made by Senator Ray, who was so anxious to point out that we were talking not about a senator-elect but a senator-designate. If you have a look at subparagraph (a) of the motion, Senator Bolkus refers to the person that we are talking about as a senator-elect, not as a senator-designate. It is up to the Labor Party, who are pursuing this line, to get their terminology right and decide exactly what it is and what it ought be.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not change the substance of the issue.

—Senator Murphy interjects and says that it does not change the substance of the issue. I would have thought that if you are dealing with these sorts of technical matters you would try to get it as right as possible. I do not think it makes much difference. It was Senator Ray, in his contribution, who was wanting to correct our side of the chamber, telling us that it was a senator-designate and not a senator-elect. Yet the very motion that he was talking to was referring to a `senator-elect'.

SPEECH.PARA: As I pointed out at the beginning, we have a situation where we are dealing with somebody's future. I believe that natural justice ought to come into play. Senator Schacht was very big on that in his discussion, and said that natural justice demands that the matter be dealt with. He is saying that natural justice demands that the matter be dealt with in this chamber in the absence of Senator-elect Ferris without giving her the opportunity to put her case to the Senate as to the circumstances surrounding the matter.

Indeed, Senator Schacht tried to make a big point out of whether or not we could believe Senator Minchin's submission to this Senate on, I believe, 22 May 1996, about the legal advice that Senator-elect Ferris had got on the issue. Surely the only person who can answer that is Senator-elect Ferris. Senator Minchin will be going only on hearsay of what Senator-elect Ferris tells him. He does not know what Senator-elect Ferris did. She does. We are talking about principles of natural justice but we are denying the person who is at the very centre of this discussion the right to make a contribution to this Senate's deliberations on the matter. That is regrettable and unfortunate.

It was somewhat strange to hear the comments of Senator Schacht, who was talking about such high principles as natural justice and yet was very quick to slip into some unnecessary political commentary that was irrelevant to the issue at stake. I have a copy of the clerk's opinion, dated 27 May 1996, in front of me. Nowhere does it say that there is an overwhelming case, as suggested by Senator Schacht. If he was dealing with the issue with the mature, statesman-like approach that he tried to assert he was using—before he could not help himself and he slipped back into the mud-slinging—he would have quoted the clerk's advice correctly. He would have directed us to the pages and the paragraphs. The clerk has given an opinion, but nowhere has he used the word `overwhelming'.

It was Senator Schacht who was suggesting to us that Senator Minchin misled the Senate about the existence of certain legal advice. I suggest there is no doubt whatsoever that Senator Schacht misled the Senate about this document which I hold, the opinion of the clerk, which clearly does not say that any of the propositions being asserted by Senator Schacht were supported on an overwhelming basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Senator Abetz has just made a claim about Senator Schacht misleading the Senate. I think that, during the debate, Senator Schacht did correct himself with regard to whether it was `overwhelming'. It was really a matter of opinion that he was expressing. I think Senator Abetz ought to withdraw his statement about Senator Schacht misleading the Senate, because that is clearly not the case. The Hansard will prove that to be so.

—There is no point of order. If there is any misrepresentation of another senator, the senator may rise at the end of the current speech of Senator Abetz and seek the chair's attention to correct anything, or to give a point of view about a misrepresentation. Certainly, there is no need for such a point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The reality is that—and I am willing to accept Senator Murphy's point—if Senator Schacht did correct himself, the Hansard record will disclose that it was only after I interjected and pointed out to him that he was in fact misrepresenting the document. If he could have got away with it, he would have done. Between the interjections, I did not pick up that Senator Schacht had corrected himself. But if Senator Schacht did correct himself it was, in my respectful submission to the Senate, a situation where he did try it, he got caught out and he then quickly corrected himself. If he did correct himself, then that matter rests. But it does not in any way deal with the issue of why he used the word `overwhelming' when it does not exist in any shape or form in the opinion from which he was seeking to quote.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 44 of the constitution deals with two types of people: those capable of being chosen and those who are sitting. They are the two categories of people. In this case, section 44 of the constitution says, `Any person who holds any office of profit under the Crown shall be incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator.' That is the relevant piece in our discussion this afternoon and this evening.

Senator-elect Ferris has clearly been chosen. There was no suggestion that she was disqualified from being chosen. Nobody on the other side of the chamber has asserted that. As Senator Harradine pointed out, if there were to be some dispute about her entitlement to be so chosen, there are procedures under the Commonwealth Electoral Act that can be pursued. If those avenues were not pursued, then that area is closed off.

So we then have to consider whether or not Senator-elect Ferris is a sitting senator. Clearly she is not a sitting senator. I put this scenario to you, Mr Acting Deputy President: it is not beyond the realm of possibility that six senators are not re-elected at a half Senate election and another six are. So there would be six sitting senators waiting for 30 June and another six who are senators-elect waiting for 30 June so as to take up their seats. In that circumstance, the opposition is trying to assert that there would in fact be 18 people to whom the provisions of the constitution could apply in relation to being in the category of a senator for the purposes of section 44.

Clearly that is not the case. The constitution quite clearly says that there can be only 12 senators in a particular state. Senator Harradine made the very neat point of order during Senator Schacht's speech and asked whether the standing orders apply to Senator-elect Ferris. Of course they do not. She does not enjoy the privileges of—dare I quote the constitution—`a sitting senator'.

That is the important point that needs to be grasped; she does not enjoy the privileges of a sitting senator. Senator Harradine very neatly pointed that out with—and I am sure he will not mind me saying so—a frivolous point of order. But it made the point very neatly and is something that ought to be exercising the collective mind of the Senate.

There is and there always was in the minds of the drafters of the constitution the situation that there would be senators-elect, because we in this place serve a fixed term, unless there is a double dissolution. One would have thought that the drafters of the constitution would have known that there would have been the three categories: those capable of being chosen; those who are currently, like Senator-elect Ferris, in limbo land, the senators-elect who do not get any privileges of office; and those who are sitting senators.

The drafters of the constitution did not refer to senators-elect but referred to only the people going through the process of being chosen and those who are sitting as senators. So I think a very long bow is being drawn by the opposition in this matter. The constitution, I believe, is very clear and speaks for itself in relation to the categorisation of Senator-elect Ferris.

TALK.START.PARA: —So why did she give the money back?

—Senator Coates interjects, `Why did she give the money back?' I suppose most people act with a degree of precaution. If there is some potential difficulty, why try to perpetuate that difficulty? But it does not deal with the actual question of whether she was the holder of an office of profit under the Crown during the period between her election and the time she takes up her appointment on 1 July. I think most of the senators opposite know the situation that Senator Minchin was not in a position to appoint Ms Ferris to his staff.
—He did; yes, he did.

—Senator Murphy is getting excited now and saying, `Yes, he did.' But we all know the facts: that under section 12 of the Member of Parliament (Staff) Act, the MOPS Act as we refer to it, the minister needed to approve the appointment and that was never forthcoming. So there was an intention but it was never consummated. The contract was never actually entered into. That is a very important and fine point. It is interesting to see that none of those opposite have dealt with the Christine Wheeler QC opinion. They just skate over that. With respect, I think it is somewhat more detailed than the Clerk's opinion in that area. I think it deals with the issues in a more forthright way.

BREAK.PARA: The motion that is before us suggests that the reference ought be going to the Court of Disputed Returns under section 376 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Once again, it says `any question in respect of the qualifications of a senator' and it goes on. But we are not dealing with a senator; we are dealing with a senator‐elect. I would have thought that the drafters of this piece of legislation would have known and seen the difference between those two categories of people, because there is clearly within our system the position of a senator‐elect.

It may well be that the High Court simply says, `Under section 376, the person whom you are referring to us is not a senator and therefore we do not have jurisdiction,' and bounces it right out without even considering the argument of section 44 of the constitution. That is why we are saying to you on the other side that, if you want to overcome that hurdle and really want to come to grips with what section 44 of the constitution means, delay the matter until after 1 July. Then you will be in the situation of being able to use section 376, because then Ms Ferris will be Senator Ferris. We may well go through the farcical situation where the High Court says, `Bad luck. She's not a senator. We can't entertain your application,' and then a month or two later go through it all again. Senator Schacht talks about natural justice. Is that fair, is that reasonable, to Ms Ferris? Of course, it is not.

The other matter that I refer to is section 370 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, which tells us that no party to the petition shall, except by consent of all parties or by leave of the court, be represented by a counsel or solicitor. Who is going to be representing the Senate in the arguments? Undoubtedly counsel. Therefore, one would assume and imagine that in the case of Ms Ferris, even if there was not consent of all the parties, leave would be granted by the High Court. She will incur considerable cost—possibly only to be told first off that she is not a senator under section 376. Then the taxpayers will have to pay the costs of that hearing, I would suggest, because under section 371 the court may award costs against an unsuccessful party to a petition. Then we might have to revisit the whole issue a few months later.

The opposition, with respect, is moving with indecent haste in relation to this. I think their true motives have been exposed by the way they drafted the motion. They have been shamed out of the last three paragraphs, but Senator Schacht still could not help but make some very cheap political points. We on this side call those things the cheap shots of Senator Schacht. Why the indecent haste? If they are genuinely concerned about coming to a resolution or a court determination on section 44 for a senator‐elect or for a senator, let us find out by waiting until after 1 July to ensure that the matter can be dealt with.
Debate interrupted.
